Posts.Content: Albert: Thank you for sharing that. It was so good, and I am so pleased that your wife is doing fine. Best wishes/excellent karma, to you, and to her David
Posts.Signature: 67 yrs old March 6, 2012: Diagnosed Anaplastic Large (T-) Cell Lymphoma, Stage 1 (ALK-) 3 rounds of CHOP unsuccessful. Beginning mid-June, 2012, received 6 cycles of Brentuximab at Huntsman Cancer Institute, University of Utah. Autologous bone marrow transplant in November of 2012. 17 radiation treatments for "consolidation" purposes between Dec. 26 and Jan.17. 100 day post BMT check-up (2/26/13): NED. Pet scan on 7/10/13: Still NED. One year post transplant check-up: Still fine; NED. 18month post-translant scans, etc. All fine, save a bit of arthritis. 11/14/14: 24 month post transplant check-up--still NED. 5/15/15: No NED this time. Relapse confirmed/ started every 3 week brentuximab Allo transplant in Feb 2016. 100 day post transplant scans in June 2016 fine. 3 yr. post SCT check up: all fine, no issues.
Posts.Title: Radio Program

Posts.Content: Cinders: I think it should be possible to do yur surgery and get tx recommendations from a large cancer center, and then get the actual treatment at your local cancer center. My treatments were for the most part designed by my doctors at the Huntsman Cancer Institute in Salt Lake City (6 hours away), but at least some of my actual treatments were done at home, at our local oncology center. My guess is, where possible, major centers try to work with local ones. Good luck with your tests.....hopefully, the results will be benign so that you don't have to worry about any oncology treatments. Am keeping my fingers crossed for you! Hugs, David

Posts.Title: What would you do, living in a rural area?

Posts.Content: Lois: Welcome to the Forums. Hopefully members with more knowledge about breast cancer will stop by. I just wanted to say this is a pretty good place to hang out and get support and tons of empathy, and so you should feel free to come here and vent, etc whenever. You sound like you have been thru the ringer and still have a great attitude. That matters so much. Keep hanging in there, Lots of prayers and best wishes for you. Hugs, David

Posts.Title: Hello everyone.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by shaww I hope your girlfriend is smart enough...... to save her own life. If she is considering ignoring all the non veterinarian methods and looking for organic treatment of her cancer she may not survive to do much hiking and kayaking. here is the ONLY percentage she needs to know and understand. Breast cancer will kill her. If you love her.... i would suggest you not indulge her on this path. What shaww said. Good luck and God bless David

Posts.Title: Conventional Treatment vs. Complimentary

Posts.Content: Niki: I am very sorry to hear about your diagnosis. I am a lymphoma guy, and do not know a lot about breast cancer. Lots of people here do, however, and I am sure you will be hearing from many of them. In the meantime, while it is perfectly natural to be terrified, maintaining a positive attitude is so important. Fortunately, as you go through the process of meeting with your oncologists and nailing down the fundamentals of your treatment plan, the terror you feel now will likely be replaced for the most part by your determination to see this thing through and get to the other side in good health. That is eminently possible these days, and you are young and otherwise in good health I bet. So hang in there, and keep us all posted on how all is going. In the meanwhile, lots of hugs and good karma to you. David
